15.verse: So Ahab called up the retainers of the governors of the provinces, two hundred thirty-two of them. Behind them he mustered all the Israelite soldiery, who numbered seven thousand.

16.verse: They marched out at noon, while Ben-hadad was drinking heavily in the pavilions with the thirty-two kings who were his allies.

17.verse: When the retainers of the governors of the provinces marched out first, Ben-hadad received word that some men had marched out of Samaria.

18.verse: He answered, "Whether they have come out for peace or for war, in any case take them alive."

19.verse: But when these had come out of the city - the soldiers of the governors of the provinces with the army following them -

20.verse: each of them struck down his man. The Arameans fled with Israel pursuing them, while Ben-hadad, king of Aram, escaped on a chariot steed.

21.verse: The king of Israel went out, took the horses and chariots, and inflicted a severe defeat on Aram.

22.verse: Then the prophet went up to the king of Israel and said to him: "Go, regroup your forces. Mark well what you do, for at the beginning of the year the king of Aram will attack you."

23.verse: On the other hand, the servants of the king of Aram said to him: "Their gods are gods of mountains. That is why they defeated us. But if we fight them on level ground, we shall be sure to defeat them.

24.verse: This is what you must do: Take the kings from their posts and put prefects in their places.

25.verse: Mobilize an army as large as the army that has deserted you, horse for horse, chariot for chariot. Let us fight them on level ground, and we shall surely defeat them." He took their advice and did this.

26.verse: At the beginning of the year, Ben-hadad mobilized Aram and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.

27.verse: The Israelites, too, were called to arms and supplied with provisions; then they went out to engage the foe. The Israelites, encamped opposite them, seemed like a couple of small flocks of goats, while Aram covered the countryside.

28.verse: A man of God came up and said to the king of Israel: "The LORD says, 'Because Aram has said the LORD is a god of mountains, not a god of plains, I will deliver up to you all this large army, that you may know I am the LORD.'"

29.verse: They were encamped opposite each other for seven days. On the seventh day battle was joined, and the Israelites struck down one hundred thousand foot soldiers of Aram in one day.

30.verse: The survivors, twenty-seven thousand of them, fled into the city of Aphek, and there the wall collapsed. Ben-hadad, too, fled, and took refuge within the city, in an inside room.

31.verse: His servants said to him: "We have heard that the kings of the land of Israel are merciful kings. Allow us, therefore, to garb ourselves in sackcloth, with cords around our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare your life."

32.verse: So they dressed in sackcloth girded at the waist, and wearing cords around their heads, they went to the king of Israel. "Your servant Ben-hadad pleads for his life," they said. "Is he still alive?" the king asked. "He is my brother."

33.verse: Hearing this as a good omen, the men quickly took him at his word and said, "Ben-hadad is your brother." He answered, "Go and get him." When Ben-hadad came out to him, the king had him mount his chariot.

34.verse: Ben-hadad said to him, "I will restore the cities which my father took from your father, and you may make yourself bazaars in Damascus, as my father did in Samaria." "On these terms," Ahab replied, "I will set you free." So he made an agreement with him and then set him free.

35.verse: One of the guild prophets was prompted by the LORD to say to his companion, "Strike me." But he refused to strike him.

36.verse: Then he said to him, "Since you did not obey the voice of the LORD, a lion will kill you when you leave me." When they parted company, a lion came upon him and killed him.

37.verse: The prophet met another man and said, "Strike me." The man struck him a blow and wounded him.

38.verse: The prophet went on and waited for the king on the road, having disguised himself with a bandage over his eyes.

39.verse: As the king was passing, he called out to the king and said: "Your servant went into the thick of the battle, and suddenly someone turned and brought me a man and said, 'Guard this man. If he is missing, you shall have to pay for his life with your life or pay out a talent of silver.'

40.verse: But while your servant was looking here and there, the man disappeared." The king of Israel said to him, "That is your sentence. You have decided it yourself."

41.verse: He immediately removed the bandage from his eyes, and the king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.

42.verse: He said to him: "The LORD says, 'Because you have set free the man I doomed to destruction, your life shall pay for his life, your people for his people.'"

43.verse: Disturbed and angry, the king of Israel went off homeward and entered Samaria.

annotations.1: [22] At the beginning of the year: in the spring.

1.verse: After Solomon finished building the temple of the LORD, the royal palace, and everything else that he had planned,

2.verse: the LORD appeared to him a second time, as he had appeared to him in Gibeon.

3.verse: The LORD said to him: "I have heard the prayer of petition which you offered in my presence. I have consecrated this temple which you have built; I confer my name upon it forever, and my eyes and my heart shall be there always.

4.verse: As for you, if you live in my presence as your father David lived, sincerely and uprightly, doing just as I have commanded you, keeping my statutes and decrees,

5.verse: I will establish your throne of sovereignty over Israel forever, as I promised your father David when I said, 'You shall always have someone from your line on the throne of Israel.'

6.verse: But if you and your descendants ever withdraw from me, fail to keep the commandments and statutes which I set before you, and proceed to venerate and worship strange gods,

7.verse: I will cut off Israel from the land I gave them and repudiate the temple I have consecrated to my honor. Israel shall become a proverb and a byword among all nations,

8.verse: and this temple shall become a heap of ruins. Every passerby shall catch his breath in amazement, and ask, 'Why has the LORD done this to the land and to this temple?'

9.verse: Men will answer: 'They forsook the LORD, their God, who brought their fathers out of the land of Egypt; they adopted strange gods which they worshiped and served. That is why the LORD has brought down upon them all this evil.'"

10.verse: After the twenty years during which Solomon built the two houses, the temple of the LORD and the palace of the king -

11.verse: Hiram, king of Tyre, supplying Solomon with all the cedar wood, fir wood, and gold he wished - King Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee.

12.verse: Hiram left Tyre to see the cities Solomon had given him, but was not satisfied with them.

13.verse: So he said, "What are these cities you have given me, my brother?" And he called them the land of Cabul, as they are called to this day.

14.verse: Hiram, however, had sent king Solomon one hundred and twenty talents of gold.

15.verse: This is an account of the forced labor which King Solomon levied in order to build the temple of the LORD, his palace, Millo, the wall of Jerusalem, Hazor, Megiddo, Gezer

16.verse: (Pharaoh, king of Egypt, had come up and taken Gezer and, after destroying it by fire and slaying all the Canaanites living in the city, had given it as dowry to his daughter, Solomon's wife;

17.verse: Solomon then rebuilt Gezer), Lower Beth-horon,

18.verse: Baalath, Tamar in the desert of Judah,

19.verse: all his cities for supplies, cities for chariots and for horses, and whatever else Solomon decided should be built in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and in the entire land under his dominion.

20.verse: All the non-Israelite people who remained in the land, descendants of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites

21.verse: whose doom the Israelites had been unable to accomplish, Solomon conscripted as forced laborers, as they are to this day.

22.verse: But Solomon enslaved none of the Israelites, for they were his fighting force, his ministers, commanders, adjutants, chariot officers, and charioteers.

23.verse: The supervisors of Solomon's works who policed the people engaged in the work numbered five hundred and fifty.

24.verse: As soon as Pharaoh's daughter went up from the City of David to her palace, which he had built for her, Solomon built Millo.

25.verse: Three times a year Solomon used to offer holocausts and peace offerings on the altar which he had built to the LORD, and to burn incense before the LORD; and he kept the temple in repair.

26.verse: King Solomon also built a fleet at Ezion-geber, which is near Elath on the shore of the Red Sea in the land of Edom.

27.verse: In this fleet Hiram placed his own expert seamen with the servants of Solomon.

28.verse: They went to Ophir, and brought back four hundred and twenty talents of gold to King Solomon.

annotations.1: [14] One hundred and twenty talents of gold: approximately three million six hundred thousand dollars.
annotations.2: [15] Millo: probably means a filling, and may refer to an artificial earthwork or platform of stamped ground south of the temple area. It was begun by David ( 2 Sam 5:9); cf 1 Kings 9:24; 11:27
annotations.3: [26] Ezion-geber . . . Edom: the first mention of maritime commerce in the Israelite kingdom (to which the land of Edom was subject after its conquest by King David; cf 2 Sam 8:14)

1.verse: Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the River to the land of the Philistines, down to the border of Egypt; they paid Solomon tribute and were his vassals as long as he lived.

2.verse: Solomon's supplies for each day were thirty kors of fine flour, sixty kors of meal,

3.verse: ten fatted oxen, twenty pasture-fed oxen, and a hundred sheep, not counting harts, gazelles, roebucks, and fatted fowl.

4.verse: He ruled over all the land west of the Euphrates, from Tiphsah to Gaza, and over all its kings, and he had peace on all his borders round about.

5.verse: Thus Judah and Israel lived in security, every man under his vine or under his fig tree from Dan to Beer-sheba, as long as Solomon lived.

6.verse: Solomon had four thousand stalls for his twelve thousand chariot horses.

7.verse: These commissaries, one for each month, provided food for King Solomon and for all the guests at the royal table. They left nothing unprovided.

8.verse: For the chariot horses and draft animals also, each brought his quota of barley and straw to the required place.

9.verse: Moreover, God gave Solomon wisdom and exceptional understanding and knowledge, as vast as the sand on the seashore.

10.verse: Solomon surpassed all the Cedemites and all the Egyptians in wisdom.

11.verse: He was wiser than all other men - than Ethan the Ezrahite, or Heman, Chalcol, and Darda, the musicians - and his fame spread throughout the neighboring nations.

12.verse: Solomon also uttered three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered a thousand and five.

13.verse: He discussed plants, from the cedar on Lebanon to the hyssop growing out of the wall, and he spoke about beasts, birds, reptiles, and fishes.

14.verse: Men came to hear Solomon's wisdom from all nations, sent by all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.

15.verse: When Hiram, king of Tyre, heard that Solomon had been anointed king in place of his father, he sent an embassy to him; for Hiram had always been David's friend.

16.verse: Solomon sent back this message to Hiram:

17.verse: "You know that my father David, because of the enemies surrounding him on all sides, could not build a temple in honor of the LORD, his God, until such a time as the LORD should put these enemies under the soles of his feet.

18.verse: But now the LORD, my God, has given me peace on all sides. There is no enemy or threat of danger.

19.verse: So I purpose to build a temple in honor of the LORD, my God, as the LORD predicted to my father David when he said: 'It is your son whom I will put upon your throne in your place who shall build the temple in my honor.'

20.verse: Give orders, then, to have cedars from the Lebanon cut down for me. My servants shall accompany yours, since you know that there is no one among us who is skilled in cutting timber like the Sidonians, and I will pay you whatever you say for your servants' salary."

21.verse: When he had heard the words of Solomon, Hiram was pleased and said, "Blessed be the LORD this day, who has given David a wise son to rule this numerous people."

22.verse: Hiram then sent word to Solomon, "I agree to the proposal you sent me, and I will provide all the cedars and fir trees you wish.

23.verse: My servants shall bring them down from the Lebanon to the sea, and I will arrange them into rafts in the sea and bring them wherever you say. There I will break up the rafts, and you shall take the lumber. You, for your part, shall furnish the provisions I desire for my household."

24.verse: So Hiram continued to provide Solomon with all the cedars and fir trees he wished;

25.verse: while Solomon every year gave Hiram twenty thousand kors of wheat to provide for his household, and twenty thousand measures of pure oil.

26.verse: The LORD, moreover, gave Solomon wisdom as he promised him, and there was peace between Hiram and Solomon, since they were parties to a treaty.

27.verse: King Solomon conscripted thirty thousand workmen from all Israel.

28.verse: He sent them to the Lebanon each month in relays of ten thousand, so that they spent one month in the Lebanon and two months at home. Adoniram was in charge of the draft.

29.verse: Solomon had seventy thousand carriers and eighty thousand stonecutters in the mountain,

30.verse: in addition to three thousand three hundred overseers, answerable to Solomon's prefects for the work, directing the people engaged in the work.

31.verse: By order of the king, fine, large blocks were quarried to give the temple a foundation of hewn stone.

32.verse: Solomon's and Hiram's builders, along with the Gebalites, hewed them out, and prepared the wood and stones for building the temple.

1.verse: At that time Abijah, son of Jeroboam, took sick.

2.verse: So Jeroboam said to his wife, "Get ready and disguise yourself so that none will recognize you as Jeroboam's wife. Then go to Shiloh, where you will find the prophet Ahijah. It was he who predicted my reign over this people.

3.verse: Take along ten loaves, some cakes, and a jar of preserves, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the child."

4.verse: The wife of Jeroboam obeyed. She made the journey to Shiloh and entered the house of Ahijah who could not see because age had dimmed his sight.

5.verse: The LORD had said to Ahijah: "Jeroboam's wife is coming to consult you about her son, for he is sick. This is what you must tell her. When she comes, she will be in disguise."

6.verse: So Ahijah, hearing the sound of her footsteps as she entered the door, said, "Come in, wife of Jeroboam. Why are you in disguise? I have been commissioned to give you bitter news.

7.verse: Go, tell Jeroboam, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I exalted you from among the people and made you ruler of my people Israel.

8.verse: I deprived the house of David of the kingdom and gave it to you. Yet you have not been like my servant David, who kept my commandments and followed me with his whole heart, doing only what pleased me.

9.verse: You have done worse than all who preceded you: you have gone and made for yourself strange gods and molten images to provoke me; but me you have cast behind your back.

10.verse: Therefore, I am bringing evil upon the house of Jeroboam: I will cut off every male in Jeroboam's line, whether slave or freeman in Israel, and will burn up the house of Jeroboam completely, as though dung were being burned.

11.verse: When one of Jeroboam's line dies in the city, dogs will devour him; when one of them dies in the field, he will be devoured by the birds of the sky. For the LORD has spoken!'

12.verse: So leave; go home! As you step inside the city, the child will die,

13.verse: and all Israel will mourn him and bury him, for he alone of Jeroboam's line will be laid in the grave, since in him alone of Jeroboam's house has something pleasing to the LORD, the God of Israel, been found.

14.verse: Today, at this very moment, the LORD will raise up for himself a king of Israel who will destroy the house of Jeroboam.

15.verse: The LORD will strike Israel like a reed tossed about in the water and will pluck out Israel from this good land which he gave their fathers, scattering them beyond the River, because they made sacred poles for themselves and thus provoked the LORD.

16.verse: He will give up Israel because of the sins Jeroboam has committed and caused Israel to commit."

17.verse: So Jeroboam's wife started back; when she reached Tirzah and crossed the threshold of her house, the child died.

18.verse: He was buried with all Israel mourning him, as the LORD had prophesied through his servant the prophet Ahijah.

19.verse: The rest of the acts of Jeroboam, with his warfare and his reign, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

20.verse: The length of Jeroboam's reign was twenty-two years. He rested with his ancestors, and his son Nadab succeeded him as king.

21.verse: Rehoboam, son of Solomon, reigned in Judah. He was forty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city in which, out of all the tribes of Israel, the LORD chose to be honored. His mother was the Ammonite named Naamah.

22.verse: Judah did evil in the sight of the LORD, and by their sins angered him even more than their fathers had done.

23.verse: They, too, built for themselves high places, pillars, and sacred poles, upon every high hill and under every green tree.

24.verse: There were also cult prostitutes in the land. Judah imitated all the abominable practices of the nations whom the LORD had cleared out of the Israelites' way.

25.verse: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak, king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem.

26.verse: He took everything, including the treasures of the temple of the LORD and those of the royal palace, as well as all the gold shields made under Solomon.

27.verse: To replace them, King Rehoboam had bronze shields made, which he entrusted to the officers of the guard on duty at the entrance of the royal palace.

28.verse: Whenever the king visited the temple of the LORD, those on duty would carry the shields, and then return them to the guardroom.

29.verse: The rest of the acts of Rehoboam, with all that he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.

30.verse: There was constant warfare between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.

31.verse: Rehoboam rested with his ancestors; he was buried with them in the City of David. His mother was the Ammonite named Naamah. His son Abijam succeeded him as king.

annotations.1: [25] In the fifth year . . . Shishak, king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem: c. 926 B. C. According to 2 Chron 12:1-12, the repentance of King Rehoboam and of the princes of Israel after the warning of the prophet Shemaiah diverted the actual attack on Jerusalem. Shishak, however, carried off the treasures of the temple of the LORD and of the king's palace ( 2 Chron 12:9). A bas-relief of this Pharaoh in the temple of Amon at Karnak commemorates his conquest of some hundred and fifty Palestinian and Transjordanian cities and towns.

1.verse: King Solomon loved many foreign women besides the daughter of Pharaoh (Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites),

2.verse: from nations with which the LORD had forbidden the Israelites to intermarry, "because," he said, "they will turn your hearts to their gods." But Solomon fell in love with them.

3.verse: He had seven hundred wives of princely rank and three hundred concubines, and his wives turned his heart.

4.verse: When Solomon was old his wives had turned his heart to strange gods, and his heart was not entirely with the LORD, his God, as the heart of his father David had been.

5.verse: By adoring Astarte, the goddess of the Sidonians, and Milcom, the idol of the Ammonites,

6.verse: Solomon did evil in the sight of the LORD; he did not follow him unreservedly as his father David had done.

7.verse: Solomon then built a high place to Chemosh, the idol of Moab, and to Molech, the idol of the Ammonites, on the hill opposite Jerusalem.

8.verse: He did the same for all his foreign wives who burned incense and sacrificed to their gods.

9.verse: The LORD, therefore, became angry with Solomon, because his heart was turned away from the LORD, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice

10.verse: (for though the LORD had forbidden him this very act of following strange gods, Solomon had not obeyed him).

11.verse: So the LORD said to Solomon: "Since this is what you want, and you have not kept my covenant and my statutes which I enjoined on you, I will deprive you of the kingdom and give it to your servant.

12.verse: I will not do this during your lifetime, however, for the sake of your father David; it is your son whom I will deprive.

13.verse: Nor will I take away the whole kingdom. I will leave your son one tribe for the sake of my servant David and of Jerusalem, which I have chosen."

14.verse: The LORD then raised up an adversary to Solomon: Hadad the Edomite, who was of the royal line in Edom.

15.verse: Earlier, when David had conquered Edom, Joab, the general of the army, while going to bury the slain, put to death every male in Edom.

16.verse: Joab and all Israel remained there six months until they had killed off every male in Edom.

17.verse: Meanwhile, Hadad, who was only a boy, fled toward Egypt with some Edomite servants of his father.

18.verse: They left Midian and passing through Paran, where they picked up additional men, they went into Egypt to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who gave Hadad a house, appointed him rations, and assigned him land.

19.verse: Hadad won great favor with Pharaoh, so that he gave him in marriage the sister of Queen Tahpenes, his own wife.

20.verse: Tahpenes' sister bore Hadad a son, Genubath. After his weaning, the queen kept him in Pharaoh's palace, where he then lived with Pharaoh's own sons.

21.verse: When Hadad in Egypt heard that David rested with his ancestors and that Joab, the general of the army, was dead, he said to Pharaoh, "Give me leave to return to my own country."

22.verse: Pharaoh said to him, "What do you lack with me, that you are seeking to return to your own country?" "Nothing," he said, "but please let me go!"

23.verse: God raised up against Solomon another adversary, in Rezon, the son of Eliada, who had fled from his lord, Hadadezer, king of Zobah,

24.verse: when David defeated them with slaughter. Rezon gathered men about him and became leader of a band, went to Damascus, settled there, and became king in Damascus.

25.verse: He was an enemy of Israel as long as Solomon lived; this added to the harm done by Hadad, who made a rift in Israel by becoming king over Edom.

26.verse: Solomon's servant Jeroboam, son of Nebat, an Ephraimite from Zeredah with a widowed mother, Zeruah, also rebelled against the king.

27.verse: This is why he rebelled. King Solomon was building Millo, closing up the breach of his father's City of David.

28.verse: Jeroboam was a man of means, and when Solomon saw that he was also an industrious young man, he put him in charge of the entire labor force of the house of Joseph.

29.verse: At that time Jeroboam left Jerusalem, and the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite met him on the road. The two were alone in the area, and the prophet was wearing a new cloak.

30.verse: Ahijah took off his new cloak, tore it into twelve pieces,

31.verse: and said to Jeroboam: "Take ten pieces for yourself; the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'I will tear away the kingdom from Solomon's grasp and will give you ten of the tribes.

32.verse: One tribe shall remain to him for the sake of David my servant, and of Jerusalem, the city I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel.

33.verse: The ten I will give you because he has forsaken me and has worshiped Astarte, goddess of the Sidonians, Chemosh, god of Moab, and Milcom, god of the Ammonites; he has not followed my ways or done what is pleasing to me according to my statutes and my decrees, as his father David did.

34.verse: Yet I will not take any of the kingdom from Solomon himself, but will keep him a prince as long as he lives for the sake of my servant David, whom I chose, who kept my commandments and statutes.

35.verse: But I will take the kingdom from his son and will give it to you - that is, the ten tribes.

36.verse: I will give his son one tribe, that my servant David may always have a lamp before me in Jerusalem, the city in which I choose to be honored.

37.verse: I will take you; you shall reign over all that you desire and shall become king of Israel.

38.verse: If, then, you heed all that I command you, follow my ways, and please me by keeping my statutes and my commandments like my servant David, I will be with you. I will establish for you, as I did for David, a lasting dynasty; I will give Israel to you.

39.verse: I will punish David's line for this, but not forever.'"

40.verse: When Solomon tried to have Jeroboam killed for his rebellion, he escapedto King Shishak, in Egypt, where he remained until Solomon's death.

41.verse: The rest of the acts of Solomon, with all his deeds and his wisdom, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of Solomon.

42.verse: The time that Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel was forty years.

43.verse: Solomon rested with his ancestors; he was buried in his father's City of David, and his son Rehoboam succeeded him as king.

annotations.1: [1-3,7] The glorious rise of Solomon, his piety and wisdom, administrative skill and wealth, the extension of his kingdom, his prestige among neighboring rulers, his reign of peace, above all his friendship with God-these are now eclipsed by his sins of intermarriage with great numbers of pagan wives and the consequent forbidden worship of their gods ( Exodus 34:11-16; Deut 7:1-5). His construction of temples in their honor merited the punishment of loss of a united kingdom to his posterity, and the opposition of adversaries to himself ( 1 Kings 11:14, 23-37). Hadad the Edomite rebelled against Solomon at the beginning of his reign ( 1 Kings 11:25). Rezon of Syria established a new kingdom in Damascus; Jeroboam of Israel constituted the greatest threat because of his revolt from within. This threefold threat culminated in the breakup of Solomon's kingdom.

1.verse: The LORD spoke against Baasha to Jehu, son of Hanani, and said:

2.verse: "Inasmuch as I lifted you up from the dust and made you ruler of my people Israel, but you have imitated the conduct of Jeroboam and have caused my people Israel to sin, provoking me to anger by their sins,

3.verse: I will destroy you, Baasha, and your house;

4.verse: I will make your house like that of Jeroboam, son of Nebat. If anyone of Baasha's line dies in the city, dogs shall devour him; if he dies in the field, he shall be devoured by the birds of the sky."

5.verse: The rest of the acts of Baasha, with all his valor and accomplishments, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

6.verse: Baasha rested with his ancestors; he was buried in Tirzah, and his son Elah succeeded him as king.

7.verse: (Through the prophet Jehu, son of Hanani, the LORD had threatened Baasha and his house, because of all the evil Baasha did in the sight of the LORD, provoking him to anger by his evil deeds, so that he became like the house of Jeroboam; and because he killed Nadab.)

8.verse: In the twenty-sixth year of Asa, king of Judah, Elah, son of Baasha, began his two-year reign over Israel in Tirzah.

9.verse: His servant Zimri, commander of half his chariots, plotted against him. As he was in Tirzah, drinking to excess in the house of Arza, superintendent of his palace in Tirzah,

10.verse: Zimri entered; he struck and killed him in the twenty-seventh year of Asa, king of Judah, and reigned in his place.

11.verse: Once he was seated on the royal throne, he killed off the whole house of Baasha, not sparing a single male relative or friend of his.

12.verse: Zimri destroyed the entire house of Baasha, as the LORD had prophesied to Baasha through the prophet Jehu,

13.verse: because of all the sins which Baasha and his son Elah committed and caused Israel to commit, provoking the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger by their idols.

14.verse: The rest of the acts of Elah, with all that he did, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

15.verse: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa, king of Judah, Zimri reigned seven days in Tirzah. The army was besieging Gibbethon of the Philistines

16.verse: when they heard that Zimri had formed a conspiracy and had killed the king. So that day in the camp all Israel proclaimed Omri, general of the army, king of Israel.

17.verse: Omri marched up from Gibbethon, accompanied by all Israel, and laid siege to Tirzah.

18.verse: When Zimri saw the city was captured, he entered the citadel of the royal palace and burned down the palace over him. He died

19.verse: because of the sins he had committed, doing evil in the sight of the LORD by imitating the sinful conduct of Jeroboam, thus causing Israel to sin.

20.verse: The rest of the acts of Zimri, with the conspiracy he carried out, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

21.verse: At that time the people of Israel were divided, half following Tibni, son of Ginath, to make him king, and half for Omri.

22.verse: The partisans of Omri prevailed over those of Tibni, son of Ginath. Tibni died and Omri became king.

23.verse: In the thirty-first year of Asa, king of Judah, Omri became king; he reigned over Israel twelve years, the first six of them in Tirzah.

24.verse: He then bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two silver talents and built upon the hill, naming the city he built Samaria after Shemer, the former owner.

25.verse: But Omri did evil in the LORD'S sight beyond any of his predecessors.

26.verse: He closely imitated the sinful conduct of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, causing Israel to sin and to provoke the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger by their idols.

27.verse: The rest of the acts of Omri, with all his valor and accomplishments, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

28.verse: Omri rested with his ancestors; he was buried in Samaria, and his son Ahab succeeded him as king.

29.verse: In the thirty-eighth year of Asa, king of Judah, Ahab, son of Omri, became king of Israel; he reigned over Israel in Samaria for twenty-two years.

30.verse: Ahab, son of Omri, did evil in the sight of the LORD more than any of his predecessors.

31.verse: It was not enough for him to imitate the sins of Jeroboam, son of Nebat. He even married Jezebel, daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Sidonians, and went over to the veneration and worship of Baal.

32.verse: Ahab erected an altar to Baal in the temple of Baal which he built in Samaria,

33.verse: and also made a sacred pole. He did more to anger the LORD, the God of Israel, than any of the kings of Israel before him.

34.verse: During his reign, Hiel from Bethel rebuilt Jericho. He lost his first-born son, Abiram, when he laid the foundation, and his youngest son, Segub, when he set up the gates, as the LORD had foretold through Joshua, son of Nun.

1.verse: Ahab told Jezebel all that Elijah had done - that he had put all the prophets to the sword.

2.verse: Jezebel then sent a messenger to Elijah and said, "May the gods do thus and so to me if by this time tomorrow I have not done with your life what was done to each of them."

3.verse: Elijah was afraid and fled for his life, going to Beer-sheba of Judah. He left his servant there

4.verse: and went a day's journey into the desert, until he came to a broom tree and sat beneath it. He prayed for death: "This is enough, O LORD! Take my life, for I am no better than my fathers."

5.verse: He lay down and fell asleep under the broom tree, but then an angel touched him and ordered him to get up and eat.

6.verse: He looked and there at his head was a hearth cake and a jug of water. After he ate and drank, he lay down again,

7.verse: but the angel of the LORD came back a second time, touched him, and ordered, "Get up and eat, else the journey will be too long for you!"

8.verse: He got up, ate and drank; then strengthened by that food, he walked forty days and forty nights to the mountain of God, Horeb.

9.verse: There he came to a cave, where he took shelter. But the word of the LORD came to him, "Why are you here, Elijah?"

10.verse: He answered: "I have been most zealous for the LORD, the God of hosts, but the Israelites have forsaken your covenant, torn down your altars, and put your prophets to the sword. I alone am left, and they seek to take my life."

11.verse: Then the LORD said, "Go outside and stand on the mountain before the LORD; the LORD will be passing by." A strong and heavy wind was rending the mountains and crushing rocks before the LORD - but the LORD was not in the wind. After the wind there was an earthquake - but the LORD was not in the earthquake.

12.verse: After the earthquake there was fire - but the LORD was not in the fire. After the fire there was a tiny whispering sound.

13.verse: When he heard this, Elijah hid his face in his cloak and went and stood at the entrance of the cave. A voice said to him, "Elijah, why are you here?"

14.verse: He replied, "I have been most zealous for the LORD, the God of hosts. But the Israelites have forsaken your covenant, torn down your altars, and put your prophets to the sword. I alone am left, and they seek to take my life."

15.verse: "Go, take the road back to the desert near Damascus," the LORD said to him. "When you arrive, you shall anoint Hazael as king of Aram.

16.verse: Then you shall anoint Jehu, son of Nimshi, as king of Israel, and Elisha, son of Shaphat of Abel-meholah, as prophet to succeed you.

17.verse: If anyone escapes the sword of Hazael, Jehu will kill him. If he escapes the sword if Jehu, Elisha will kill him.

18.verse: Yet I will leave seven thousand men in Israel - all those who have not knelt to Baal or kissed him."

19.verse: Elijah set out, and came upon Elisha, son of Shaphat, as he was plowing with twelve yoke of oxen; he was following the twelfth. Elijah went over to him and threw his cloak over him.

20.verse: Elisha left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said, "Please, let me kiss my father and mother good-bye, and I will follow you." "Go back!" Elijah answered. "Have I done anything to you?"

21.verse: Elisha left him and, taking the yoke of oxen, slaughtered them; he used the plowing equipment for fuel to boil their flesh, and gave it to his people to eat. Then he left and followed Elijah as his attendant.

annotations.1: [11-13] Compare these divine manifestations to Elijah with those to Moses ( Exodus 19:1-23; 33:21-23; 34:5) on the same Mount Horeb (Sinai) ( Deut 4:10-15). Though various phenomena, such as wind, storms, earthquakes, fire ( Exodus 19:18-19), herald the divine presence, they do not constitute the presence itself which, like the tiny whispering sound, is imperceptible and bespeaks the spirituality of God. It was fitting that Elijah, whose mission it was to re-establish the covenant and restore the pure faith, should have returned to Horeb where the covenant was revealed to Moses and through him to the Israelite people ( Exodus 3:1-4, 17; 33:18- 34:9). Moses and Elijah appeared with Christ at the time of his transfiguration ( Matthew 17:1-9; Mark 9:1-7; Luke 9:28-36).
annotations.2: [15-17] Elijah himself carried out only the third of the commissions entrusted to him ( 1 Kings 19:19-21); Elisha was deputed to perform the first in person ( 2 Kings 8:7-19), and the second through one of his followers ( 2 Kings 9:1-10)
annotations.3: [19-21] Elijah's act of throwing his mantle over the shoulders of Elisha expressed the divine call to share the prophetic mission. Elisha's prompt response through destruction of his plow and oxen is an example of total obedience and detachment from his former manner of living in order to promote the glory of God

verses.1:
1 Kings
Introduction
The two Books of Kings were originally, like 1 Sam; 2 Sam - a single historical work. In conjunction with the Books of Samuel, they extend the consecutive history of Israel from the birth of Samuel to the destruction of Jerusalem in 587 B.C. This combined work is designed as a religious history; hence in Kings the temple, which is the chosen site for the worship of Yahweh, occupies the center of attention
The Books of Kings show clearly the theological bent of a Deuteronomic editor. In them, as already in Judges, material from various sources, such as the "book of the acts of Solomon" ( 1 Kings 11:41) and the "book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel" ( 1 Kings 14:19), is forged into structural unity by an editor whose principal interest is in the fidelity to Yahweh of rulers and people. The reigns of individual kings are adapted to an editorial framework consisting of a presentation and an obituary notice for each, in stereotyped formulas. In between, the achievements of the king are reported-above all, his fidelity or lack of fidelity to Yahweh. The faithful prosper; the unfaithful pay for their defections. Since this is basically a narrative of sin and retribution, it would not be inappropriate to entitle the Books of Kings "The Rise and Fall of the Israelite Monarchy.&quot
Without minimizing the complexity of the process by which this material was transmitted for many centuries, one may speak of two editions of the Books: the first at some time between 621 B.C. and 597 B.C., and the second, final edition during the Exile; probably shortly after Jehoiachin was released from his Babylonian prison (561 B.C.)
1 Kings carries the history of Israel from the last days and death of David to the accession in Samaria of Ahaziah, son of Ahab, near the end of the reign of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah. Judgment is passed on Ahaziah's reign but the details are given only later, in 2 Kings. We should note the two large cycles of traditions which grew up around the great prophetic figures of Elijah and Elisha, the former in 1 Kings and the latter chiefly in 2 Kings. These cycles, which interrupt the sequence of regnal chronicles, were very probably preserved and transmitted by the prophetic communities to which there are references in the same traditions. The Elijah cycle is the more important since it dramatically underscores Israel's critical struggle with the religion of Canaan
The principal divisions of the Books of Kings are
I. The Reign of Solomon ( 1 Kings 1:1- 11:43)
II. Judah and Israel to the Time of Ahab ( 1 Kings 12:1- 16:34)
III. Stories of the Prophets ( 1 Kings 17:1- 22:54)
IV. The Kingdoms of Israel and Judah ( 2 Kings 1:1- 17:41)
V. The Kingdom of Judah after 721 B.C. ( 2 Kings 18:1- 25:30

1.verse: At the order of Solomon, the elders of Israel and all the leaders of the tribes, the princes in the ancestral houses of the Israelites, came to King Solomon in Jerusalem, to bring up the ark of the LORD'S covenant from the city of David (which is Zion).

2.verse: All the men of Israel assembled before King Solomon during the festival in the month of Ethanim (the seventh month).

3.verse: When all the elders of Israel had arrived, the priests took up the ark;

4.verse: they carried the ark of the LORD and the meeting tent with all the sacred vessels that were in the tent. (The priests and Levites carried them.)

5.verse: King Solomon and the entire community of Israel present for the occasion sacrificed before the ark sheep and oxen too many to number or count.

6.verse: The priests brought the ark of the covenant of the LORD to its place beneath the wings of the cherubim in the sanctuary, the holy of holies of the temple.

7.verse: The cherubim had their wings spread out over the place of the ark, sheltering the ark and its poles from above.

8.verse: The poles were so long that their ends could be seen from that part of the holy place adjoining the sanctuary; however, they could not be seen beyond. (They have remained there to this day.)

9.verse: There was nothing in the ark but the two stone tablets which Moses had put there at Horeb, when the LORD made a covenant with the Israelites at their departure from the land of Egypt.

10.verse: When the priests left the holy place, the cloud filled the temple of the LORD

11.verse: so that the priests could no longer minister because of the cloud, since the LORD'S glory had filled the temple of the LORD.

12.verse: Then Solomon said, "The LORD intends to dwell in the dark cloud;

13.verse: I have truly built you a princely house, a dwelling where you may abide forever."

14.verse: The king turned and greeted the whole community of Israel as they stood.

15.verse: He said to them: "Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who with his own mouth made a promise to my father David and by his hand has brought it to fulfillment. It was he who said,

16.verse: 'Since the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city out of any tribe of Israel for the building of a temple to my honor; but I choose David to rule my people Israel.'

17.verse: When my father David wished to build a temple to the honor of the LORD, the God of Israel,

18.verse: the LORD said to him, 'In wishing to build a temple to my honor, you do well.

19.verse: It will not be you, however, who will build the temple; but the son who will spring from you, he shall build the temple to my honor.'

20.verse: And now the LORD has fulfilled the promise that he made: I have succeeded my father David and sit on the throne of Israel, as the LORD foretold, and I have built this temple to honor the LORD, the God of Israel.

21.verse: I have provided in it a place for the ark in which is the covenant of the LORD, which he made with our fathers when he brought them out of the land of Egypt."

22.verse: Solomon stood before the altar of the LORD in the presence of the whole community of Israel, and stretching forth his hands toward heaven,

23.verse: he said, "LORD, God of Israel, there is no God like you in heaven above or on earth below; you keep your covenant of kindness with your servants who are faithful to you with their whole heart.

24.verse: You have kept the promise you made to my father David, your servant. You who spoke that promise, have this day, by your own power, brought it to fulfillment.

25.verse: Now, therefore, LORD, God of Israel, keep the further promise you made to my father David, your servant, saying, 'You shall always have someone from your line to sit before me on the throne of Israel, provided only that your descendants look to their conduct so that they live in my presence, as you have lived in my presence.'

26.verse: Now, LORD, God of Israel, may this promise which you made to my father David, your servant, be confirmed.

27.verse: "Can it indeed be that God dwells among men on earth? If the heavens and the highest heavens cannot contain you, how much less this temple which I have built!

28.verse: Look kindly on the prayer and petition of your servant, O LORD, my God, and listen to the cry of supplication which I, your servant, utter before you this day.

29.verse: May your eyes watch night and day over this temple, the place where you have decreed you shall be honored; may you heed the prayer which I, your servant, offer in this place.

30.verse: Listen to the petitions of your servant and of your people Israel which they offer in this place. Listen from your heavenly dwelling and grant pardon.

31.verse: "If a man sins against his neighbor and is required to take an oath sanctioned by a curse, when he comes and takes the oath before your altar in this temple,

32.verse: listen in heaven; take action and pass judgment on your servants. Condemn the wicked and punish him for his conduct, but acquit the just and establish his innocence.

33.verse: "If your people Israel sin against you and are defeated by an enemy, and if then they return to you, praise your name, pray to you, and entreat you in this temple,

34.verse: listen in heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them back to the land you gave their fathers.

35.verse: "If the sky is closed, so that there is no rain, because they have sinned against you and you afflict them, and if then they repent of their sin, and pray, and praise your name in this place,

36.verse: listen in heaven and forgive the sin of your servant and of your people Israel, teaching them the right way to live and sending rain upon this land of yours which you have given to your people as their heritage.

37.verse: "If there is famine in the land or pestilence; or if blight comes, or mildew, or a locust swarm, or devouring insects; if an enemy of your people besieges them in one of their cities; whatever plague or sickness there may be,

38.verse: if then any one (of your entire people Israel) has remorse of conscience and offers some prayer or petition, stretching out his hands toward this temple,

39.verse: listen from your heavenly dwelling place and forgive. You who alone know the hearts of all men, render to each one of them according to his conduct; knowing their hearts, so treat them

40.verse: that they may fear you as long as they live on the land you gave our fathers.

41.verse: "To the foreigner, likewise, who is not of your people Israel, but comes from a distant land to honor you

42.verse: (since men will learn of your great name and your mighty hand and your outstretched arm), when he comes and prays toward this temple,

43.verse: listen from your heavenly dwelling. Do all that the foreigner asks of you, that all the peoples of the earth may know your name, may fear you as do your people Israel, and may acknowledge that this temple which I have built is dedicated to your honor.

44.verse: "Whatever the direction in which you may send your people forth to war against their enemies, if they pray to you, O LORD, toward the city you have chosen and the temple I have built in your honor,

45.verse: listen in heaven to their prayer and petition, and defend their cause.

46.verse: "When they sin against you (for there is no man who does not sin), and in your anger against them you deliver them to the enemy, so that their captors deport them to a hostile land, far or near,

47.verse: may they repent in the land of their captivity and be converted. If then they entreat you in the land of their captors and say, 'We have sinned and done wrong; we have been wicked';

48.verse: if with their whole heart and soul they turn back to you in the land of the enemies who took them captive, pray to you toward the land you gave their fathers, the city you have chosen, and the temple I have built in your honor,

50.verse: Forgive your people their sins and all the offenses they have committed against you, and grant them mercy before their captors, so that these will be merciful to them.

51.verse: For they are your people and your inheritance, whom you brought out of Egypt, from the midst of an iron furnace.

52.verse: "Thus may your eyes be open to the petition of your servant and to the petition of your people Israel. Hear them whenever they call upon you,

53.verse: because you have set them apart among all the peoples of the earth for your inheritance, as you declared through your servant Moses when you brought our fathers out of Egypt, O Lord GOD."

54.verse: When Solomon finished offering this entire prayer of petition to the LORD, he rose from before the altar of the LORD, where he had been kneeling with his hands outstretched toward heaven.

55.verse: He stood and blessed the whole community of Israel, saying in a loud voice:

56.verse: "Blessed be the LORD who has given rest to his people Israel, just as he promised. Not a single word has gone unfulfilled of the entire generous promise he made through his servant Moses.

57.verse: May the LORD, our God, be with us as he was with our fathers and may he not forsake us nor cast us off.

58.verse: May he draw our hearts to himself, that we may follow him in everything and keep the commands, statutes, and ordinances which he enjoined on our fathers.

59.verse: May this prayer I have offered to the LORD, our God, be present to him day and night, that he may uphold the cause of his servant and of his people Israel as each day requires,

60.verse: that all the peoples of the earth may know the LORD is God and there is no other.

61.verse: You must be wholly devoted to the LORD, our God, observing his statutes and keeping his commandments, as on this day."

62.verse: The king and all Israel with him offered sacrifices before the LORD.

63.verse: Solomon offered as peace offerings to the LORD twenty-two thousand oxen and one hundred twenty thousand sheep. Thus the king and all the Israelites dedicated the temple of the LORD.

64.verse: On that day the king consecrated the middle of the court facing the temple of the LORD; he offered there the holocausts, the cereal offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings, because the bronze altar before the LORD was too small to hold these offerings.

65.verse: On this occasion Solomon and all the Israelites, who had assembled in large numbers from Labo of Hamath to the Wadi of Egypt, celebrated the festival before the LORD, our God, for seven days.

66.verse: On the eighth day he dismissed the people, who bade the king farewell and went to their homes, rejoicing and happy over all the blessings the LORD had given to his servant David and to his people Israel.

annotations.1: [6-9] The transfer of the ark of the covenant into the newly constructed temple building, and the oracle of God's acceptance ( 1 Kings 9:3-9), and his act of possession ( 1 Kings 8:10-13), constituted the temple's solemn dedication, and made of it the abiding dwelling of God among his people for which David had hoped ( 2 Sam 6:12-15; 7:1-3). The concurrence of the feast of Booths marks an appropriate transition of God's dwelling among nomadic tribes to his permanent abode among a settled people.
annotations.2: [33-34,46-53] These references to deportation of Israelites to a hostile land are an expansion of Solomon's prayer dating from the Babylonian exile four centuries later

1.verse: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, son of Nebat, Abijam became king of Judah;

2.verse: he reigned three years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Maacah, daughter of Abishalom.

3.verse: He imitated all the sins his father had committed before him, and his heart was not entirely with the LORD, his God, like the heart of his grandfather David.

4.verse: Yet for David's sake the LORD, his God, gave him a lamp in Jerusalem, raising up his son after him and permitting Jerusalem to endure;

5.verse: because David had pleased the LORD and did not disobey any of his commands as long as he lived, except in the case of Uriah the Hittite.

6.verse: There was war between Abijam and Jeroboam.

7.verse: The rest of Abijam's acts, with all that he did, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.

8.verse: Abijam rested with his ancestors; he was buried in the City of David, and his son Asa succeeded him as king.

9.verse: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam, king of Israel, Asa, king of Judah, began to reign;

10.verse: he reigned forty-one years in Jerusalem. His grandmother's name was Maacah, daughter of Abishalom.

11.verse: Asa pleased the LORD like his forefather David,

12.verse: banishing the temple prostitutes from the land and removing all the idols his father had made.

13.verse: He also deposed his grandmother Maacah from her position as queen mother, because she had made an outrageous object for Asherah. Asa cut down this object and burned it in the Kidron Valley.

14.verse: The high places did not disappear; yet Asa's heart was entirely with the LORD as long as he lived.

15.verse: He brought into the temple of the LORD his father's and his own votive offerings of silver, gold, and various utensils.

16.verse: There was war between Asa and Baasha, king of Israel, as long as they both reigned.

17.verse: Baasha, king of Israel, attacked Judah and fortified Ramah to prevent communication with Asa, king of Judah.

18.verse: Asa then took all the silver and gold remaining in the treasuries of the temple of the LORD and of the royal palace. Entrusting them to his ministers, King Asa sent them to Ben-hadad, son of Tabrimmon, son of Hezion, king of Aram, resident in Damascus. He said:

19.verse: "There is a treaty between you and me, as there was between your father and my father. I am sending you a present of silver and gold. Go, break your treaty with Baasha, king of Israel, that he may withdraw from me."

20.verse: Ben-hadad agreed with King Asa and sent the leaders of his troops against the cities of Israel. They attacked Ijon, Dan, Abel-beth-maacah, and all Chinnereth, besides all the land of Naphtali.

21.verse: When Baasha heard of it, he left off fortifying Ramah, and stayed in Tirzah.

22.verse: Then King Asa summoned all Judah without exception, and they carried away the stones and beams with which Baasha was fortifying Ramah. With them King Asa built Geba of Benjamin and Mizpeh.

23.verse: The rest of the acts of Asa, with all his valor and accomplishments, and the cities he built, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah. In his old age, Asa had an infirmity in his feet.

24.verse: He rested with his ancestors; he was buried in his forefather's City of David, and his son Jehoshaphat succeeded him as king.

25.verse: In the second year of Asa, king of Judah, Nadab, son of Jeroboam, became king of Israel; he reigned over Israel two years.

26.verse: He did evil in the LORD'S sight, imitating his father's conduct and the sin which he had caused Israel to commit.

27.verse: Baasha, son of Ahijah, of the house of Issachar, plotted against him and struck him down at Gibbethon of the Philistines, which Nadab and all Israel were besieging.

28.verse: Baasha killed him in the third year of Asa, king of Judah, and reigned in his stead.

29.verse: Once he was king, he killed off the entire house of Jeroboam, not leaving a single soul to Jeroboam but destroying him utterly, according to the warning which the LORD had pronounced through his servant, Ahijah the Shilonite,

30.verse: because of the sins Jeroboam committed and caused Israel to commit, by which he provoked the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger.

31.verse: The rest of the acts of Nadab, with all that he did, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

32.verse: (There was war between Asa and Baasha, king of Israel, as long as they lived.)

33.verse: In the third year of Asa, king of Judah, Baasha, son of Ahijah, began his twenty-four-year reign over Israel in Tirzah.

34.verse: He did evil in the LORD'S sight, imitating the conduct of Jeroboam and the sin he had caused Israel to commit.

annotations.1: [18] Ben-hadad . . . king of Aram: Ben-hadad I, third successor of Rezon, who had thrown off the yoke of the Israelites during the reign of Solomon and become king of Aram ( 1 Kings 11:23, 24).
